text: ah now that's a good question.... I have been very lucky in my career to have had some amazing opportunities, particularly to have been at the forefront of some very large arbitrations and to have had a lot of responsibility in them. On the other hand, since I started work I have discovered philosophy by doing two part time masters, and doing reasonably well at it, so I would be interested to know how my career would have been different had I chosen to follow that academic path rather than go into consultancy and essentially do philosophy "for fun". At the end of the day, I guess the answer is that I am happy with where I am in life, so probably I wouldn't change anything. But it's a close call!
How do most people enter this profession?

by joining consultancies. I joined a small one, but there are a number of large consultancies that a number of my colleagues have come from. Then you get more experience managing projects and getting to know clients, and progress from there.
How long did you or your colleagues take to rise to the top?
well i'm certainly not at the top! It took me 8 years to get to AD level, which I think is probably quick, but there are people who have done similar in much quicker time.

I was mainly just lucky to be in the right place at the right time and get lots of specialist experience. Career progression can be a mix of hard work and making sure you're in the right position to benefit from any opportunities that come along
